title: Confusing type suggested for enums with inner fields

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
### Code

```Rust
#[derive(Debug, PartialEq)]
pub enum MyError {
    ErrorType(Details),
}

#[derive(Debug, PartialEq)]
pub enum Details {
    NoDetails,
}

pub fn return_result() -> Result<(), MyError> {
    todo!()
}

#[cfg(test)]
mod tests {
    use super::*;

    #[test]
    fn check_error_type() {
        let err = return_result().unwrap_err();
        assert_eq!(err, MyError::ErrorType);
    }
}
```


### Current output

```Shell
maxim@maxbook:~/dev/rust_being_unfriendly$ cargo check --tests
    Checking rust_being_unfriendly v0.1.0 (/home/maxim/dev/rust_being_unfriendly)
error[E0308]: mismatched types
  --> src/lib.rs:22:9
   |
3  |     ErrorType(Details),
   |     --------- fn(Details) -> MyError {MyError::ErrorType} defined here
...
22 |         assert_eq!(err, MyError::ErrorType);
   |         ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ expected enum `MyError`, found fn item
   |
   = note: expected enum `MyError`
           found fn item `fn(Details) -> MyError {MyError::ErrorType}`
```


### Desired output

```Shell
enum variant `MyError::ErrorType` must contain inner value of type `(Details)`
```


### Rationale and extra context

Even though the compiler is correct strictly speaking, the error message is not very clear. It's not obvious at the first glance where this `fn(Details) -> MyError ...` closure type comes from.

### Other cases

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_
